Award.AwardTitle: The National Alliance for Doctoral Studies in the Mathematical Sciences: Infrastructure
Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Alliance for Doctoral Studies in the Mathematical Sciences ("The Alliance") is an alliance of mathematical sciences faculty and students with the following goals:

1. To increase the number of doctoral degrees in the mathematical sciences among groups that have been traditionally underrepresented in these fields.
2. To improve placement of students from these groups in doctoral programs in disciplines that recruit undergraduate mathematics majors.
3. To increase the number of Ph.D.s from these groups who enter the professoriate in the mathematical sciences as well as other appropriate professions.
4. To increase funded research collaborations among faculty members at universities with mathematical sciences doctoral programs and faculty members at colleges and universities focused on undergraduate students.
5. To foster the growth of a community of mathematical scientists that promotes a diverse workforce.

The Alliance brings together more than 200 faculty from colleges and universities that serve large percentages of undergraduate students from underrepresented backgrounds and nearly 100 of their counterparts at masters and doctoral granting mathematical sciences departments. It serves more than 400 undergraduate and master's level students from families, regions, and ethnic backgrounds that have had little prior contact with the culture and profession of research in the mathematical sciences. The Alliance has had initial success and it is growing rapidly, in numbers, in programs, and in its ties to other parts of the profession. This proposal provides funds to support Alliance programming and personnel to allow the organization to create an appropriate governance structure and infrastructure to support this growth as well as to begin the critical evaluation and research that will guide the Alliance in its growth and provide data and outcomes to those who would develop such programs in other STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Alliance for Doctoral Study in the Mathematical Sciences is a community of faculty mentors working together to ensure that every student who comes from a background that is underrepresented in the mathematical sciences and has the ambition, talent and desire to pursue doctoral study in these fields will have the opportunity to do so in a supportive and welcoming environment.  With the support of the NSF-DMS Infrastructure program, this community of mentors has grown from 120 faculty in 2011 to 540 faculty in 2016; the students whom these faculty serve has grown during this time from just under 500 to over 1700.  NSF support has enabled the Alliance to develop two key objectives: the annual Field of Dreams Conference and the Facilitated Graduate Admissions Procedure (F-GAP).  These activities provide the critical transition between the undergraduate experience and doctoral study; they have resulted in more than 200 Alliance students entering graduate programs in the past three years.  When these students enter graduate school, they will most likely do so in a department that has formed an Alliance Graduate Program Group, a group of faculty with sufficient seniority and numbers that they can create an environment in which a diverse group of students will thrive.  The number of these Graduate Program Groups has grown from 13 in 2011 to 42 in 2016.  As the Alliance has grown it has begun to foster the creation of communities of faculty mentors based in particular regions.  These regional alliances have proved successful and have significantly increased the number of students that the Alliance is able to serve.  It was understood from the outset that the Alliance was to be self-sustaining at the end of the present funding period.  This goal has now been achieved.  The intellectual merit of the Alliance is that it trains and prepares students who have had little prior contact with the mathematical sciences professions to enter and thrive in those professions.  This will lead, as historically it always has led, to a renewal and enrichment of those professions.  The broader impact is twofold.  First, by reaching out to populations both minority and majority who have been culturally remote from the sciences, the Alliance and its activities can lessen the distance between these groups at a critical moment.  Second, by providing a new model for mentoring it can lead the way in other STEM fields, a process that has already begun in Physics.  The success of the Alliance would have been impossible without the support and guidance of NSF-DMS: thank you!!
